Laws ch. 223, \u00a7\u00a71 e.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:

Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1851).proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1851).support_reasoning: The proposition is very general: that plaintiff brings a negligence action under Massachusetts common law and relies on general negligence principles recognized by Massachusetts courts. Brown v. Kendall is a foundational Massachusetts case articulating core negligence principles, including duty of ordinary care, unavoidable accident, and burden of proof, and is routinely cited as authoritative Massachusetts common-law negligence doctrine. The opinion’s reasoning explicitly sets out these general principles, so it squarely supports the proposition as an authoritative Massachusetts negligence source.
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1851).relevant_excerpt: “We think, as the result of all the authorities, the rule is correctly stated by Mr. Greenleaf, that the plaintiff must come prepared with evidence to show either that the intention was unlawful, or that the defendant was in fault; for if the injury was unavoidable, and the conduct of the defendant was free from blame, he will not be liable… if it appears that the defendant was doing a lawful act, and unintentionally hit and hurt the plaintiff, then unless it also appears… that the defendant is chargeable with some fault, negligence, carelessness, or want of prudence, the plaintiff… is not entitled to recover.”

Roby v. Woman\u2019s Hosp. of Worcester,.raw_text: Roby v. Woman’s Hosp. of Worcester, 367 Mass. 304 (1975)
Roby v. Woman\u2019s Hosp. of Worcester,.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Roby v. Woman\u2019s Hosp. of Worcester,.case_name: Board of Assessors v. Iron Rail Fund of Girls Clubs of America, Inc.
Roby v. Woman\u2019s Hosp. of Worcester,.support_reasoning: The case is a Massachusetts tax exemption decision concerning charitable-use status of real estate and the January 1 assessment date. It does not involve a negligence action, common-law negligence principles, or any discussion of tort standards or duties. Therefore it does not support the proposition that a plaintiff brings a negligence action under Massachusetts common law or relies on general negligence principles.
Roby v. Woman\u2019s Hosp. of Worcester,.relevant_excerpt: “The assessors do not dispute the proposition that as long as Iron Rail carried on its camping program for girls on the property in question, it was exempt from taxation. … Nevertheless, with exceptions not here applicable, in this Commonwealth January 1 of each year is the assessment date. G. L. c. 59, § 21. The rule which flows from this is settled: ‘It is the use of the property at the time when the tax is assessed which determines whether it is exempt from taxation or not.’”

Kline v. Mass. Elec. Co., 357 Mass. 226.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Kline v. Mass. Elec. Co., 357 Mass. 226.case_name: Lally v. Peter Bent Brigham Hospital
Kline v. Mass. Elec. Co., 357 Mass. 226.support_reasoning: The case concerns the statutory priority and pro rata distribution of funeral and last-illness expenses in an insolvent estate under G.L. c. 198, § 1. It does not involve a negligence action, common-law tort principles, or general negligence doctrines of Massachusetts. Therefore, it does not support the broad proposition that plaintiff’s negligence action relies on Massachusetts common-law negligence principles and related authorities.
Kline v. Mass. Elec. Co., 357 Mass. 226.relevant_excerpt: “The sole issue is whether G. L. c. 198, § 1, relating to the distribution of an insolvent estate, recognizes whether a debt due to an undertaker for funeral expenses and to a hospital for expenses of the last sickness are within a single classification so that they each take a pro rata share or whether one is preferred over the other.”

Fitzgerald v. Boston Edison Co., 341 Mas.raw_text: Fitzgerald v. Boston Edison Co., 341 Mass. 90 (1960)
Fitzgerald v. Boston Edison Co., 341 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Fitzgerald v. Boston Edison Co., 341 Mas.support_reasoning: The case is an eminent domain/takings damages case focused on procedural rules for bills of exceptions and the admissibility and method of expert valuation testimony. It does not involve a plaintiff bringing a negligence action, nor does it discuss or apply general common-law negligence principles. Therefore it cannot properly be cited as authority for the broad proposition about Massachusetts common-law negligence and related authorities or statutes.
Fitzgerald v. Boston Edison Co., 341 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "Several of Edison’s objections to the report relate to the auditor’s action in permitting an expert witness to make use of a plan of a proposed subdivision of the petitioner’s land. The auditor did not exceed the bounds of the reasonable discretion which he had to permit an expert witness to state the reasons for his opinion and to explain those reasons with reference to potential uses of the land and to plans or chalks illustrative of such uses... One substantial question was raised by the auditor’s interrogation of one McSweeney, an expert witness, to obtain his opinion of the diminution in value of the petitioner’s land caused by the taking..."

DiGiambattista v. McCarthy, 34 Mass. App.raw_text: DiGiambattista v. McCarthy, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 248 (1993)
DiGiambattista v. McCarthy, 34 Mass. App.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
DiGiambattista v. McCarthy, 34 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The proposition is an extremely general statement that the plaintiff brings a negligence action under Massachusetts common law and relies on general negligence principles and authorities. DiGiambattista v. McCarthy (the cited case name) does not appear in the provided text; instead, the excerpt is from Sarnafil, Inc. v. Peerless Ins. Co., which concerns insurance coverage, breach of policy conditions, and the insurer’s duty of good faith, not general negligence standards. Thus, this opinion neither articulates nor applies foundational Massachusetts negligence principles in a way that supports the broad proposition stated.
DiGiambattista v. McCarthy, 34 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: "Inherent in the contracts of insurance was Peerless’s obligation of good faith towards Sarnafil. That obligation was to deal with Sarnafil with ‘candor and fairness,’ ... and not to act ‘to defeat any intended coverage or diminish the protection purchased by the insured’.... An unjustified disclaimer of coverage or of the obligation to defend a lawsuit ... prevents an insurer from holding the insured thereafter to strict performance of the policy requirements..."

Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n, 3.raw_text: Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass’n, 365 Mass. 184 (1974)
Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n, 3.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n, 3.case_name: Essex Theatre Corp. v. Police Commissioner
Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n, 3.support_reasoning: The quoted text is only a brief concurrence referencing another case (Commonwealth v. Horton) and does not discuss negligence, common-law negligence principles, or any Massachusetts statutes or authorities governing negligence. Therefore, this portion of Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass’n does not provide support for the broad proposition about general negligence principles in Massachusetts. The citation is inapposite to the stated proposition.
Ginty v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n, 3.relevant_excerpt: "Hennessey, J. (concurring). I concur in the result and reasoning of the court’s opinion and would add the comments contained in my concurring opinion in Commonwealth v. Horton, ante, 164."

Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Ma.raw_text: Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Mass. 354 (1970)
Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Ma.case_name: Henry B. Byors & Sons, Inc. v. Board of Water Commissioners of Northborough
Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a negligence action under Massachusetts common law and reliance on general negligence principles. This opinion is an equity/declaratory judgment case about the validity of a municipal water ‘demand charge’ and allocation of contractual responsibility for that charge between a housing authority, a general contractor, and a subcontractor. It does not involve a tort claim, negligence standards, duty, breach, causation, or damages, and thus provides no authority for general negligence principles under Massachusetts law.
Plunkett v. S. Boston Auto Sales, 358 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “This is a bill in equity for a declaratory decree… The bill seeks a declaration as to the validity of a ‘demand charge’ imposed by the water commissioners as a condition precedent to providing water service… and if it is valid, whether Byors is legally obligated to pay the demand charge under the terms of the subcontract with Sarno and the terms of the general contract between Sarno and the housing authority.”

Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Ma.raw_text: Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Mass. 96 (1977)
Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Ma.case_name: Fortune v. National Cash Register Co.
Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a plaintiff bringing a negligence action under Massachusetts common law and relying on general negligence principles. This case, however, is a contract/employment case about an at‑will employment agreement, an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and bonus/commission rights; it does not discuss negligence standards or common-law negligence principles. Therefore, it does not support the cited negligence proposition.
Saarinen v. Bay State Realty Co., 373 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "We hold that NCR’s written contract contains an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and a termination not made in good faith constitutes a breach of the contract. … In so holding we are merely recognizing the general requirement in this Commonwealth that parties to contracts and commercial transactions must act in good faith toward one another. Good faith and fair dealing between parties are pervasive requirements in our law; it can be said fairly, that parties to contracts or commercial transactions are bound by this standard."

Shea v. Former Owner, 376 Mass. 1 (1978).proposition: Plaintiff brings this negligence action under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and relies on the general negligence principles recognized and applied by Massachusetts courts and authoritative legal authorities, including but not limited to the following statutes, authorities and authorities of general applicability:
Shea v. Former Owner, 376 Mass. 1 (1978).support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about murder, robbery, and suppression of exculpatory evidence under Brady and Agurs. It does not involve a civil negligence action, does not discuss common-law negligence standards, and does not interpret negligence-related statutes or tort principles. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the general negligence principles the proposition references.
Shea v. Former Owner, 376 Mass. 1 (1978).relevant_excerpt: On the face of things the Commonwealth, by its failure to produce the Virginia statements favorable to the defendant, violated the rule of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83,87 (1963), amplified in United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 97, 106 (1976), that suppression by the prosecution of requested material evidence which is favorable to the accused is a denial of due process.
